The item has meanwhile been paid by the project, and it is expected that for the remaining duration of the project, costs will be as budgeted. In this case, which is the best formula to calculate EaC (Estimate at Completion)?

During a company event, you had the opportunity to talk to a colleague project manager. He told you that in his current project actual costs are 15% under cumulated costs budgeted for today. What do you think?
options: The information given to you by the colleague is not sufficient to assess project performance
The project will probably be completed with total costs remaining under budget until the end
A significant cost increase during the further course of the project will probably bring the costs back to baseline level
Original cost forecasting and budgeting for the project must have been poor to allow this variance

questions.question: What does EVM stand for in project management?
Which technique is used to determine the cost of a project by analyzing the costs of each activity?
In project cost management, what is a cost baseline?
options: An approved version of the budget used to track actual performance
The sum of all project expenses

questions.question: Which document includes a detailed breakdown of project costs?
Which type of cost estimating technique uses historical data from similar projects?
Which project management knowledge area is focused on estimating, budgeting, and controlling costs?

A project manager is assessing the possibility of maintaining the efficiency to compensate for the budget gap. The following is the available data: AC=$60K, EV=$65K, BAC=$250K. How likely can he complete the project on the planned budget?
Which of the following is included in the total project budget but is not included in the cost performance baseline?
questions.explanation: Contingency reserves are included in the cost baseline and are for identified risks. Work package estimates are included in the cost baseline and the total project budget. Control accounts are management control points used for measuring project performance. Management reserves are for unanticipated or unforeseen risks and are not included in the cost baseline, but they are added to the total allowable amount for the project (the total project budget). PMBOK Guide, Sixth Edition, Page 248.

questions.question: When considering influences that could have an impact on cost management which of the following would you be the least concerned about?
options: Marketplace conditions, i.e. currency exchange rates, products, and services available
questions.explanation: The project team should be concerned with organizational financial procedures and controls (classified as OPA and given in answer A) and EEFs (answers B and D) when determining what to put into the cost management plan. The proposed budget is not the same thing as preapproved financial resources. The preapproved financial resources would be considered a constraint of the project. The proposed budget of the project is developed after estimating costs and would be the last thing the team would be concerned about. PMBOK Guide, Sixth Edition, Page 236 and 237.

questions.question: Which key performance indicator (KPI) is used to measure cost efficiency in project schedule management?
What is the primary objective of Project Cost Management?
options: To ensure the project is completed within the approved budget

questions.question: Which process involves developing a cost management plan?
What does the Cost Management Plan define?
options: How project costs will be estimated, budgeted, and controlled

questions.question: Which technique is used to estimate costs by comparing the project to similar past projects?
What is the purpose of Earned Value Management (EVM) in cost management?
options: To measure project performance in terms of cost

questions.question: A CPI value greater than 1 indicates:
options: The project is ahead of schedule

questions.question: Which technique is used to identify the cause of cost variances?
What does TCPI (To-Complete Performance Index) represent?
options: Cost efficiency required to achieve specific project goals
Total cost variance of the project
The difference between actual costs and planned costs
The budget at completion for the project

questions.question: What is the purpose of cost forecasting?
options: To determine the cost performance index

questions.question: Which process involves comparing actual project costs against the cost baseline?
In EVM, what is the term used for the authorized budget assigned to the work to be accomplished?
What is the main purpose of Cost Control?
options: To measure project performance against the schedule
To ensure that the project remains within the approved budget

questions.question: Which metric is used to measure the cost efficiency required to complete the remaining work within the approved budget?
The process of comparing actual costs against planned costs to identify cost variances is called:
What is the term used for the total budget for the project?
When should cost forecasts be performed in a project?
options: Only during the project initiation phase
Only during the project closing phase
Once during the project planning phase

What is the key purpose of contingency reserves in cost management?
options: To cover known risks that impact the project budget
To allocate funds for unforeseen risks
To cover the cost of project changes

options: To compare actual costs with planned costs

questions.question: You are a PMP leading the Public Relations (PR) department of TechCo, a publicly traded company. The tax authorities have alerted your company about potential misuse of expense reimbursements, including fraudulent claims, by 250 employees. Upon investigation, your company finds these allegations to be true. As the PR head, what could be your next step?
options: As a PR head, you are loyal to TechCo and are not willing to disclose this news to the shareholders, as you believe this is a matter between your company and the tax authorities
You are worried about the negative publicity and impact on stock prices this news can have, and your professional ethics require that you ensure none of this information leaks to the media
In your position, you authorize the publication of this news to the shareholders after internal discussions and ensuring the news is devoid of sensitive company information
You immediately call for a press conference and provide them with all the details because you don't want to be seen as withholding news, unlike the last time when you released news on the 7th day
questions.explanation: As a PR head, it's important to balance the company's interests with the need for transparency with shareholders. While avoiding unnecessary panic or damage to the company's reputation, being honest about significant issues is also important. This option represents the best balance of these considerations.

questions.question: What is the primary role of a Project Management Office (PMO)?
options: To make all the decisions in a project
To provide project management support functions
To take responsibility for the project's outcome
questions.explanation: The primary role of a Project Management Office (PMO) is to support project managers in a variety of ways which can include providing project management guidance, standards, procedures, documentation, and templates.

questions.question: John, the sponsor, requested Mark, the manager, to advise if the deliverables were completed as scheduled. Mark informed John that the project is significantly behind schedule and will likely exceed budget. John, however, would like Mark to consider a change that Sarah, one of the stakeholders, has insisted on including in the project. Among the following, which one factor is John LEAST LIKELY to IGNORE:
questions.explanation: Integrated Change Control is reviewing all change requests, approving changes, and managing changes to deliverables, organizational process assets, project documents, and the project management plan. Given the project is significantly behind schedule and likely to go over budget, John, as the sponsor, is least likely to ignore the process of managing changes to the project.

questions.question: An organization has a policy that a change control board (CCB) must review all change requests for every project and that the CCB follows the recommended activities outlined in the PMBOK® Guide. Project managers and the project team do not serve as members of the CCb) Based on this scenario, which of the following activities might be performed by members of the CCB?
questions.explanation: The Change Control Board (CCB) is responsible for reviewing, evaluating, approving, delaying, or rejecting changes to the project and for recording and communicating such decisions. After a change request is approved, the CCB will monitor the implementation of the approved changes.

questions.question: A company has authorized a dedicated change control board (CCB) to review and evaluate all change requests submitted for any project. If the project sponsor is a member of the CCB, which of the following best describes an individual or group that can request a change on a project?
questions.explanation: Any stakeholder involved in the project can request a change. This includes the project manager, project sponsor, project team, and other stakeholders. The Change Control Board (CCB) would then approve the change request.

questions.question: You were asked to include more work in the project scope during a meeting with some project stakeholders. You had access to the project's correspondence prior to signing the project charter, and you are confident that the project sponsor declined financing for the scope requested by the stakeholders. What is the best course of action?
options: Include the job if there is time in the project timetable
Inform stakeholders that the scope cannot be accommodated
Examine the impact of including the work
Inform the project sponsor of the stakeholders' request
questions.explanation: There is no reason to persuade the project sponsor to include the work (letters c and a) based on the information provided. While you can notify the project sponsor (letter d), it is best to say no. The best approach is to identify the fundamental cause of the project sponsor's rejection; however, that option is not listed.

questions.question: Despite his lack of project management experience, Robert has been designated as the project manager. Because he must work in a matrix structure to successfully manage the project, the following communication expectations will be met:
questions.explanation: Communication in a matrix organization might be difficult because the project involves people from various organizations.

questions.question: Ben and Anna are both project managers in a shaky matrix structure. They both realized that their abilities were severely constrained because Ben works as an expediter, and Anna is more likely a coordinator. What is the distinction between an expediter and a coordinator?
options: An expediter has some level of authority
An expediter reports to a manager
An expediter is given authority over the project
An expediter is not permitted to make decisions about the project
questions.explanation: The expediter's role is only to expedite project activity. He or she has no decision-making authority. The project coordinator, on the other hand, has some decision-making ability, but this is determined by his supervisor or functional manager.

questions.question: Adam, Bryan, Chris, and Dave (all project managers) are chatting in a coffee shop about their work. In general, they are having problems managing their initiatives. Bryan is dissatisfied with the piling response he receives from stakeholders. Adam discusses how difficult it is to get employees to deliver on time. Chris prefers to focus on the advantages of a matrix organization. Which idea should Dave bring to the table if he wants to reach an agreement on the matrix organization?
options: Better project manager resource allocation control
questions.explanation: Keep in mind that if a question on the PMP exam does not specify what it is compared to, the default point of comparison is a functional organization.

questions.question: In a project-oriented organization, the project team:
options: There will not always be a home base
Has no devotion to the project
Reports to a large number of supervisors or managers
Responsible for reporting to the functional manager
questions.explanation: The fundamental disadvantage of the project-oriented company is that once the project is done, the team will be dispersed without a functional department or home base to which they can return.

questions.question: The production manager and a department manager disagreed over a change to an important work package. The production manager approached you and requested you to prepare the necessary papers to allow the necessary alterations. The scenario exemplifies the following:
questions.explanation: Because there is no need to review the change, this is an excellent example of a project expediter's role.

questions.question: Debbie is a team member who is feeling overwhelmed by a large number of duties from various stakeholders. Who has the authority to give tasks to her if she works in a functional organization?
questions.explanation: The functional manager (typically the project manager's boss) has the authority to assign work in a functional organization.

questions.question: A software development project is now in the planning phase, and five stakeholders approached the project manager to inquire about the organization's new project management methodology. The stakeholders want to know where the methodology came from and why it is superior to the current technique. Furthermore, the stakeholders have a close relationship with the project manager, and the entire group has been working together for more than five years. The group must employ new terms, such as "corrective response," with the new methodology, which causes some concern because they are unsure how the methodology will affect their work. What should a project manager do?
options: Inform the project management office (PMO) of the three stakeholders' concerns
Inform the stakeholders that you will send them information on critical project changes
Give a list of new project management words and their definitions
Maintain your power as the manager even if you are friends with the stakeholders
questions.explanation: Have you considered that this item has multiple right answers? You are not by yourself. However, there is just one correct answer for this one. There are numerous things you may perform as a project manager. However, you should just consider your team's and organization's present capacity. Remember that the PMO is in charge of organizational policies, and as the manager, you must ensure that stakeholders understand the changes in project methodology by sending them to the PMO, which serves as the organization's policy-centric institution.

questions.question: In a project-oriented organization, the highest power is held by _________________.
questions.explanation: Remember that the project manager has the most authority in a projectoriented organization because the entire company is structured around projects.

questions.question: When making project changes, pay special attention to:
options: Notifying the sponsor of the changes
questions.explanation: As a project manager, you should take a proactive approach. In this item, the sole proactive choice is to avoid unneeded alterations.

questions.question: Elijah is a new project manager with no previous project management expertise. He has been requested to create a project plan. Which of the following can he count on to work on a plan to boost the project's success rate?
questions.explanation: Elijah must rely on the experience of others because he has no project management experience. He can find out more about this by analyzing historical documents from previous projects.

questions.question: Which of the following is the best description of your work as a project integrator?
options: Gather all team members that are committed to the same goals
Insert all of the project's components into the program
Combine all project parts into one cohesive whole
Assist team members in comprehending the project
questions.explanation: Remember that project integration relates to the unity of activities rather than team members, thus letter a is incorrect.

questions.question: What four values are identified in the PMI Code of Ethics and Professional Conduct?
questions.explanation: The PMI Code of Ethics and Professional Conduct is based on these four values. These values are considered most important to the project management community.

questions.question: How are the project management principles and the PMI Code of Ethics related?
options: The principles are based on the Code of Ethics
The Code of Ethics is based on the principles
questions.explanation: The project management principles and the PMI Code of Ethics are complementary. They are not identical or based on each other, but they complement each other in guiding the behavior of project management practitioners.

questions.question: The PMI Code of Ethics and Professional Conduct is based on four values. What are they?
questions.explanation: The PMI Code of Ethics and Professional Conduct is based on four primary values: responsibility, respect, fairness, and honesty.

questions.question: The project management principle 'Be a diligent, respectful, and caring steward' is aligned with which value from the PMI Code of Ethics and Professional Conduct?
questions.explanation: Being a diligent, respectful, and caring steward aligns with the PMI Code of Ethics and Professional Conduct's value of Responsibility.

questions.question: You have recently joined an organization which has recently adopted Agile to execute projects. Senior Management is complaining that Team A is not performing efficiently as compared to Team B because their velocity is regularly lower than that of Team B. What would you do in such situation?
options: Move some members of Team B to Team A
Inform Senior Management that velocity cannot be used as comparison metric between different teams
Ask Team A to improve their velocity in the upcoming iterations
Introduce reward structure which may increase motivation of Team A
questions.explanation: Individual teams decide the size of story points based upon their own estimations, which cannot be compared across teams. Since velocity is the number of story points completed during an iteration, therefore, velocity too cannot be compared between two different teams.

questions.question: A project management team wants to procure customized products which can be specified easily and are available in identical grade and quality from several vendors. The procurement documents will probably have to support what main intention?
options: Describing the needs of the project in sufficient detail to enable vendors to make suitable proposals based on each one's specific strengths
Specifying attributes of the requested deliverables in detail to get identical bids from vendors and allow selection using the "Least cost method"
Helping to clarify the approved project scope statement and giving guidelines to break it down into the WBS and the WBS dictionary of the project
Developing the risk management plan and the risk reports from those risk management reviews which have been made so far with the vendors

questions.question: According to the project plan, a contractor is scheduled to deliver the next software increment today afternoon. A regular monthly payment is due to be made to this contractor tomorrow. You and your project team received a note this morning informing you that the software delivery will be delayed by 2 weeks. What should you do right now?
options: You should delay the payment for 2 weeks too
You must immediately find and change to a different contractor
You should consult with the contractor to understand and jointly resolve the delivery issues
You should make the payment and reschedule the project incorporating the delay

questions.question: In the context of product management, how do portfolios, programs, projects, and products typically relate?
options: Each represents a different level of strategic organization
All four terms represent the same concept
Each requires a separate project manager
The terms are unrelated and used interchangeably
questions.explanation: These terms represent different levels of strategic organization within a business. Portfolios include multiple programs, which in turn include multiple projects. Products are typically the output of projects and should align with the strategic objectives at the portfolio and program levels.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the principles of project management?
options: To serve as laws or rules
To guide the behavior of people involved in projects
To serve as a code of ethics
questions.explanation: Project management principles are intended to guide the behavior of people involved in projects. They are neither prescriptive nor necessarily reflect morals or serve as a code of ethics.

questions.question: How were the principles of project management identified and developed?
options: By a single project management expert
By a small group of project management experts
By engaging a global community of project practitioners
questions.explanation: The project management principles were identified and developed by engaging a global community of project practitioners. This community represents different industries, cultural backgrounds, and organizations with different roles and experiences in various projects.

questions.question: What does "Be a diligent, respectful, and caring steward" encompass?
options: Both responsibilities within and outside the organization
Neither responsibilities within nor outside the organization
questions.explanation: Stewardship encompasses responsibilities both within and external to the organization. It includes operating in alignment with the organization, commitment to and respectful engagement of project team members, diligent oversight of organizational finances, materials, and other resources, and understanding the appropriate use of authority, accountability, and responsibility. Outside the organization, it includes responsibilities in areas such as environmental sustainability, the organization's relationship with external stakeholders, the impact of the organization or project on the market, social community, and regions in which it operates, and advancing the state of practice in professional industries.

questions.question: What does creating a collaborative project team environment involve?
questions.explanation: Creating a collaborative project team environment involves multiple contributing factors, such as team agreements, structures, and processes. These factors support a culture that enables individuals to work together and provide synergistic effects from interactions.

questions.question: What does a collaborative project team environment foster?
options: The free exchange of information and individual knowledge
The free exchange of information only
Neither the free exchange of information nor individual knowledge
questions.explanation: A collaborative project team environment fosters the free exchange of information and individual knowledge. This, in turn, increases shared learning and individual development while delivering outcomes.

questions.question: Stakeholders can influence a project in several ways. Which of the following is NOT a way stakeholders can impact a project?
options: By helping to reduce or increase project costs.
By defining success factors and participating in the evaluation of success.
By controlling the overall project management process.
By revealing the need to adjust project scope and/or requirements elements
questions.explanation: Stakeholders can influence various aspects of the project, such as the scope, schedule, cost, project team, plans, outcomes, culture, benefits realization, risk, quality, and success factors. However, they do not control the overall project management process.

questions.question: The process of stakeholder engagement can change throughout the project lifecycle. What factor most likely requires adjustments to stakeholder engagement?
options: The variation in stakeholders' interest, influence, or impact over time.
The alignment of the project with its original business case.
The size of the project team.
The type of project management methodology used
questions.explanation: The degree of a stakeholder's interest, influence, or impact may change over time, requiring adjustments to their engagement. The other options are not directly linked to stakeholder engagement.

questions.question: The business case for a project often includes several key elements. Which of the following is NOT typically included in a business case, based on the information in the text?
questions.explanation: Business case typically includes strategic alignment, risk exposure, economic feasibility, return on investment, key performance measures, evaluations, and alternative approaches.

questions.question: A project's value is its ultimate success indicator. Which of the following statements best defines value in the context of a project?
options: Value is the financial contribution to the sponsoring or receiving organization.
Value is the subjective worth, importance, or usefulness of something, which can vary between stakeholders.
Value is solely based on the customer's perceived benefit from the project result.
Value is the final deliverable of the project
questions.explanation: Value is subjective, can vary for different people and organizations, and depends on organizational strategies. The other options are aspects of value but do not encompass the full, subjective nature of value as described in the text.

questions.question: How does effective leadership contribute to a project?
options: It focuses solely on the authoritative role of a project manager.
It promotes project success, fosters shared responsibility toward the project goal and contributes to positive project outcomes.
It encourages a laissez-faire approach to project management.
It prevents any conflict within the project team
questions.explanation: Effective leadership plays a vital role in project success. Leadership skills can motivate, influence, and direct project teams toward desired outcomes, help manage obstacles and foster shared responsibility toward achieving project goals. These, in turn, contribute to positive project outcomes.

questions.question: Which of the following factors are considered when tailoring project systems?
options: The business environment, team size, uncertainty, and project complexity.
The marketing strategy, financial status, and the project manager's preference.
The geographical location of the organization and the project manager's experience.
The type of project management software and equipment available
questions.explanation: When tailoring project systems, several factors are considered, including the business environment, team size, degree of uncertainty, and project complexity. These aspects help decide how to adjust the approach, governance, and processes to suit the context.

questions.question: What is the purpose of quality activities in project management?
options: To ensure that what is delivered meets the objectives of the customer and other relevant stakeholders.
To ensure the project team completes their work on time.
To ensure that the project team is working to their full potential.
To ensure that the project's budget is not exceeded
questions.explanation: The primary purpose of quality activities in project management is to ensure that what is delivered aligns with the objectives of the customer and other relevant stakeholders. This is done to minimize resource waste, maximize the probability of attaining the desired outcomes, and prevent defects or identify them early to avoid or reduce the need for rework.

questions.question: In the context of quality, what is a requirement?
options: A condition or capability must be present in a product, service, or result to satisfy a need.
An optional feature that enhances the project's outcome.
A recommendation made by a project stakeholder.
A goal the project team sets for their personal growth and development
questions.explanation: A requirement is a condition or capability that needs to be present in a product, service, or result to satisfy a specific need. These requirements can be explicit or implicit and may come from various sources such as stakeholders, contracts, organizational policies, standards, or regulatory bodies.

questions.question: What is the overall project risk?
options: The effect of uncertainty on a particular task in the project.
The likelihood that the project will exceed its budget.
The probability that the project timeline will be extended.
The effect of uncertainty on the project as a whole, arising from all sources of uncertainty
questions.explanation: Overall, project risk arises from all sources of uncertainty and represents the effect of uncertainty on the project. The other options either narrow down the scope of the risk or need clarification on its concept.

questions.question: What factors should be considered when identifying potential risk responses in a project?
options: The significance of the risk, cost-effectiveness, realism within the project context, stakeholder agreement, and responsible ownership.
The total number of risks in the project, budget allocation for risk management, and stakeholder involvement.
The project timeline, availability of resources, and the skills of the project team.
The reputation of the project manager, the size of the project team, and the project's technical complexity
questions.explanation: Potential risk responses should be identified considering the significance of the risk, cost-effectiveness, realism within the project context, stakeholder agreement, and responsible ownership.

questions.question: What does adaptability refer to in the context of project management?
options: The ability to resist changing conditions.
The ability to respond to changing conditions.
The ability to avoid changing conditions.
The ability to predict changing conditions
questions.explanation: Adaptability is responding to changing conditions. This capacity allows a project to adapt to new circumstances and continue making progress even when conditions are not as initially planned.

questions.question: Which capabilities do NOT support adaptability and resilience in a project environment?
options: Short feedback loops to adapt quickly.
Strict adherence to initial project plans.
Diverse project teams with broad skill sets, cultures, and experience
questions.explanation: Importance of adaptability and resilience in a project environment, which requires flexibility to respond to changing conditions. Strict adherence to initial project plans contradicts this principle, as it does not allow for necessary adjustments and could be detrimental in the face of new or unforeseen factors.

questions.question: In the context of project management, what is the main difference between change management and project change control?
options: Change management involves changes to documents, deliverables, or baselines associated with the project, while project change control refers to transitioning individuals, groups, and organizations from current to future.
Change management and project change control involves changes to documents, deliverables, or baselines associated with the project.

Change management is a comprehensive, cyclic, and structured approach for transitioning individuals, groups, and organizations from a current state to a future state, while project change control involves modifications to documents, deliverables, or baselines associated with the project.
There is no difference between change management and project change control
questions.explanation: Change management refers to a comprehensive, cyclic, and structured approach for transitioning individuals, groups, and organizations from a current state to a future state. On the other hand, project change control involves identifying and documenting modifications to documents, deliverables, or baselines associated with the project and getting them approved or rejected.

questions.question: What is the nature of project management principles?
options: They are strict laws that must be followed
They serve as foundational guidelines for strategy, decision-making, and problem-solving
questions.explanation: Project management principles are not prescriptive or strict laws. They are foundational guidelines used for decision-making and problem-solving.

questions.question: How were the principles of project management identified and developed?
options: By a single project management expert
By a global community of project practitioners through multiple rounds of feedback
By the board of PMI without any external feedback
By randomly choosing principles from other management disciplines
questions.explanation: Project management principles were identified and developed through multiple rounds of feedback from a global community of project practitioners from diverse backgrounds.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a principle of project management as per PMI?
options: Create a collaborative project team environment
questions.explanation: Project management principles include creating a collaborative project team environment, embracing adaptability and resiliency, and effectively engaging with stakeholders. However, focusing only on risk mitigation is not one of the principles.

questions.question: Can principles of project management have areas of overlap with general management principles?
options: Yes, they can overlap, especially around areas like delivering value
No, project management principles are superior to general management principles
questions.explanation: Principles of project management can overlap with general management principles. For instance, both may focus on delivering value, although the methods may differ.

questions.question: When applying the principles of project management, how should they be considered?
options: As strict rules that must be followed to the letter
As suggestions that can be ignored if they don't seem relevant
As guidelines, the application of which is influenced by the project's context
As an academic exercise that has little bearing on real-world project management
questions.explanation: The principles of project management provide guidance. The context of the project and the organization influence how they are applied.

questions.question: What does the principle 'Tailor based on context' refer to?
options: Adapting clothing to fit project team members
Adapting project management approaches based on the context of the organization and project
Always using a one-size-fits-all approach to project management
Customizing the project deliverables based on customer preference
questions.explanation: 'Tailor based on context' refers to adapting the project management approach, governance, and processes to fit the context of the project and the organization.

questions.question: Why is 'Enable change to achieve the envisioned future state' important as a principle?
options: It ensures that the project remains static and predictable
It discourages any deviation from the original project plan
It emphasizes the importance of facilitating change to reach desired project outcomes
It emphasizes sticking to the original project scope at all costs
questions.explanation: 'Enable change to achieve the envisioned future state' is a principle that highlights the importance of facilitating change to reach the outcomes envisioned for the project.

questions.question: The principle 'Recognize, evaluate, and respond to system interactions' is mainly about understanding ___________ in a project environment.
questions.explanation: Recognizing, evaluating, and responding to system interactions in a project environment means understanding the interdependencies and impacts.

questions.question: The principle 'Demonstrate leadership behaviors' mainly emphasizes __________.
options: Showing the way and setting examples for the team
Solely making all decisions in the project
questions.explanation: 'Demonstrate leadership behaviors' emphasizes showing the way and setting examples for the team. It doesn't mean dictating all tasks or solely making all decisions.

questions.question: 'Build quality into processes and deliverables' as a principle is most likely to align with which general management principle?
questions.explanation: 'Build quality into processes and deliverables' aligns with the general management principle of Quality management.

questions.question: 'Navigate complexity' as a project management principle primarily deals with ___________.
options: Understanding and managing the intricacies and uncertainties of the project
Making the project as complex as possible
questions.explanation: 'Navigate complexity' involves understanding and managing the intricacies and uncertainties of the project, not avoiding complex projects or making the project as complex as possible.

questions.question: Product Management Considerations are crucial because:
options: They ensure all tasks are assigned to team members
They facilitate the completion of the project on time
They ensure the alignment of projects with organizational goals
They focus solely on product quality
questions.explanation: Product Management Considerations are crucial to aligning projects with overall business strategies, ensuring they deliver maximum value.

questions.question: Creating Value within a project primarily focuses on the following:
questions.explanation: While cost and profit are important, the primary focus of creating value within a project is meeting stakeholder expectations ranging from quality, time, cost, and other project success criteria.

questions.question: How do portfolios, programs, projects, and products relate in the context of Product Management Considerations?
options: They represent distinct, unrelated components of a business
They are organized hierarchically, from portfolios down to individual projects and products
They are interchangeable terms representing the same concept
Separate, independent teams must manage them
questions.explanation: These terms represent different levels of strategic organization in a business. Portfolios include multiple programs, which in turn include multiple projects. Products may be the output of projects and need to align with the strategic objectives at the portfolio and program levels.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes a project's value in the context of organizational strategy?
options: The financial gain realized upon project completion
The extent to which it aligns with and supports strategic objectives
The speed at which the project is completed
The level of technological innovation in the project's output
questions.explanation: While financial gain, project speed, and technological innovation may be important, the primary measure of a project's value is how well it aligns with and supports the organization's strategic goals.

questions.question: How does creating value contribute to project success?
options: By ensuring strict adherence to project timelines
By aligning the project's objectives with the stakeholders' expectations
By achieving the highest possible profit margin
By using the most advanced technology available
questions.explanation: While adherence to timelines, profit margins, and technology usage can be important, creating value for a project is primarily about aligning objectives with stakeholder expectations to meet their needs and bring about satisfaction.

questions.question: Phototech has conducted market research that shows only 25% of photographers using digital cameras eventually upload the photos they have taken, as the rest found it either too difficult to follow the upload instructions or didn't have internet connections. Phototech has identified a need for a WiFi-enabled digital camera that can take pictures and upload them automatically to a predefined website. Phototech plans to create 3 million units of these in the next 4 years and expects newer technology to replace these eventually. All of the following statements are false except:
options: The creation of the digital camera goes through the project lifecycle followed by the product life cycle
The project life cycle goes through a series of phases to create the digital camera, whereas the product life cycle includes the ideas, creation, operations, marketing, and product retirement
Phototech creating and marketing 3 million units implies that both the project life cycle and product life cycle are intertwined
The product life cycle goes through a series of phases to create the digital camera, whereas the project life cycle includes the ideas, creation, operations, marketing, and product retirement
questions.explanation: The project life cycle refers to the phases a project goes through, from initiation to closure. In contrast, the product life cycle refers to the stages a product goes through, from conception and design to market withdrawal. In this case, the project life cycle would involve creating the digital camera. In contrast, the product life cycle would involve the broader process of ideating, creating, operating, marketing, and eventually retiring the product.

questions.question: At the end of an IT project, the project deliverable is not as competitive as possible because a rival company has released more advanced software during its lifecycle. Despite the project team delivering on time and within budget, the project sponsor believes the project should have been stopped earlier. What could the project manager have done differently in this situation?
options: Implemented a more aggressive project schedule
Organized more frequent lessons-learned meetings with the project team
Initiated the project with a more innovative idea
questions.explanation: Given that the rival company's release of more advanced software has made the project deliverable less competitive, a more thorough competitor analysis could have provided early warnings of the competitor's software development, which might have led to changes in the project's direction. While more frequent lessons-learned meetings could be beneficial in general, they wouldn't necessarily have prevented the specific issue. Similarly, initiating the project with a more innovative idea might have been beneficial, but it's unclear whether this would have been possible or effective.

questions.question: How should a project manager handle a situation where project objectives are not aligned with business goals?
options: Ignore the misalignment and continue with the project
Realign project objectives with business goals through the change control process
Escalate the issue to the project team
questions.explanation: Realigning through the change control process ensures project objectives support business goals.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of a project within an organization?
options: To increase the workload of employees
To create a new department within the organization
questions.explanation: The primary purpose of a project within an organization is to create value for stakeholders. This can be achieved by creating a new product, service, or result, improving efficiency, or enabling organizational transitions.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a component of a value delivery system?
questions.explanation: While stakeholders are an important part of any project, they are not a component of the value delivery system. The value delivery system comprises portfolios, programs, projects, products, and operations.

questions.question: What is the result or consequence of a process or project?
questions.explanation: An outcome is a process or project's result or consequence. It is what is achieved after the process or project is completed.

questions.question: What is the role of a governance system within an organization?
options: To enable smooth workflows, manage issues, and support decision making
To create conflicts and challenges for the project team
To decrease the efficiency of the organization
To increase the workload of the project team
questions.explanation: The governance system in an organization is designed to enable smooth workflows, manage issues, and support decision-making. It provides a framework that guides activities and helps manage changes, issues, and risks.

questions.question: What is the function of people who provide oversight and coordination in a project?
options: To decrease the efficiency of the project
To increase the workload of the project team
To help the project team achieve the project objectives
To create conflicts within the project team
questions.explanation: The function of people who provide oversight and coordination in a project is to help the project team achieve the project objectives. They do this by orchestrating the project's work and monitoring its progress.

questions.question: What is the role of people who provide business direction and insight in a project?
options: To guide and clarify the direction of the project or product outcome
To decrease the efficiency of the project
To increase the workload of the project team
To create conflicts within the project team
questions.explanation: People who provide business direction and insight in a project guide and clarify the project's or product outcome's direction. They help prioritize requirements based on business value, dependencies, and risks.

questions.question: What is the function of people who maintain governance in a project?
options: To approve and support recommendations made by the project team
To decrease the efficiency of the project
To increase the workload of the project team
To create conflicts within the project team
questions.explanation: People who maintain governance in a project approve and support recommendations made by the project team. They also monitor project progress in achieving the desired outcomes.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a factor internal to the organization?
questions.explanation: Marketplace conditions are external to the organization. They include factors such as competitors, market share, brand recognition, and technology trends.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a factor external to the organization?
options: Social and cultural influences and issues
questions.explanation: Governance documentation is internal to the organization. It includes policies and processes that guide the organization's operations.

questions.question: What is the primary function of people who perform work and contribute insights into a project?
options: To provide the knowledge, skills, and experience necessary to produce the products and realize the outcomes of the project
To decrease the efficiency of the project
To increase the workload of the project team
To create conflicts within the project team
questions.explanation: People who perform work and contribute insights into a project provide the knowledge, skills, and experience necessary to produce the products and realize the project's outcomes. They are essential for the successful completion of the project.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes how projects deliver value to organizations and their stakeholders?
options: Through the improved quality of products
By satisfying stakeholder needs and expectations
By achieving the project scope on time and within budget
questions.explanation: By satisfying stakeholder needs and expectations. Projects deliver value through tangible benefits like profits and intangible benefits such as customer satisfaction and alignment with strategic goals.

questions.question: How do governance systems support a system for value delivery within an organization?
options: By facilitating decision-making and resource allocation processes
questions.explanation: By facilitating decision-making and resource allocation processes. Governance systems provide a framework for decision-making and resource allocation, supporting value delivery.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a function associated with projects?
questions.explanation: While marketing can be part of a broader project scope, it is not a core function associated with project management, which includes scheduling, budgeting, and staffing.

questions.question: Which of the following is an external factor that can influence the project and its value delivery?
questions.explanation: External factors like economic conditions, market trends, or regulation changes can influence project execution and its ability to deliver value.

questions.question: Organizational Governance Systems support a system for value delivery by:
questions.explanation: Organizational Governance Systems create the framework for how decisions are made, including how resources are allocated, to support value delivery.

questions.question: Which of the following is an internal factor influencing the project environment and its value delivery?
questions.explanation: Organizational culture is an internal factor that can significantly influence a project's success and ability to deliver value.

questions.question: Functions associated with projects include all of the following except:
questions.explanation: While sales can be an output or a benefit of a project, it is not a core function associated with project management like risk, scope, or stakeholder management.

questions.question: What is the primary role of governance in a project's value delivery system?
options: Assigning project tasks to team members
Making major decisions about the project's direction
Establishing a clear hierarchy within the project team
Ensuring regulatory compliance at all stages of the project
questions.explanation: Governance in a project's value delivery system primarily involves high-level decision-making to steer the project in the right direction.

questions.question: Which of the following is not typically a function associated with project management?
questions.explanation: While CRM might be a part of a larger project, it is not a core project management function. Quality, procurement, and cost management are all typical project management functions.

questions.question: Which of these is an example of an external factor influencing a project?
options: Interpersonal conflicts within the project team
A new law that changes industry regulations
questions.explanation: This is an external factor that can affect the project. The other options listed are considered internal factors.

questions.question: Which of the following illustrates the relationship between portfolios, programs, projects, and products?
options: Portfolios contain programs, which contain projects that produce products
Products are made up of projects, which form programs and portfolios
Projects, programs, and products are separate elements of a portfolio
Programs are part of projects, which are part of portfolios that produce products
questions.explanation: In a typical organization, this represents the hierarchy: Portfolios encompass programs, which are made up of projects, and projects result in the creation of products.

questions.question: Which of the following is how organizational governance systems contribute to project success?
options: By establishing guidelines for decision-making and resource allocation
By promoting the project on social media
questions.explanation: Organizational governance systems contribute to project success by setting up guidelines and frameworks that help in decision-making and allocation of resources.

questions.question: An example of an internal factor that can impact a project is:
questions.explanation: Organizational structure is an internal factor that can significantly impact a project, while changes in market demand, political instability, and natural disasters are typically considered external factors.

questions.question: Which of the following is not typically a function performed in project management?
questions.explanation: While important for an organization, sales forecasting is not a typical project management function. Project management involves cost estimation, staff recruitment, and time scheduling as key functions.

questions.question: Your project has been plagued with numerous change requests. What is the most likely reason?
options: Lack of a detailed procedure to close the project
Change management plan did not authorize a change control board
questions.explanation: Many change requests could indicate that the change management plan did not authorize a change control board (CCB). A CCB is responsible for reviewing and approving or rejecting change requests, which can help manage the number of changes on a project.

questions.question: The project manager is in the final stages of a project when a critical component fails during testing. The project sponsor approves a change request to replace the failed component. What is the next step for the project manager?
options: Assign a team member to replace the component
Update the risk register with this new risk
Schedule a meeting with the change control board
Record the failure and the replacement in the change log
questions.explanation: Given that the change request to replace the failed component has been approved, the next step would be to assign a team member to replace the component. Updating the risk register and recording the failure in the change log are important steps, but these typically come after addressing the immediate issue of the component failure.

questions.question: Who is typically responsible for approving change requests?
questions.explanation: The change control board (CCB) reviews and approves or rejects change requests.

questions.question: How should a project manager handle a significant change request that impacts the project scope?
options: Reject the change request to avoid scope creep
Submit the change request to the change control board (CCB) for evaluation
Implement the change and inform stakeholders later
questions.explanation: Significant change requests should be evaluated by the CCB to assess their impact on the project.

questions.question: During a project, a key stakeholder requests a significant change. What should the project manager do first?
options: Assess the impact of the change
Escalate the request to the project sponsor
questions.explanation: Before implementing or rejecting the change, the project manager should assess its impact on the project scope, schedule, and cost.

questions.question: A project team member suggests a change to improve project outcomes. What is the best approach for the project manager?
options: Approve the change and implement it immediately
Reject the change to avoid scope creep
Evaluate the change request and submit it to the change control board (CCB) for approval
questions.explanation: Evaluating the change ensures it aligns with project objectives, and submitting it to the CCB allows for formal review and approval.

questions.question: A change request has been approved. What is the next step for the project manager?
options: Update the project management plan and relevant documents to reflect the approved change
Inform all stakeholders of the change
Conduct a risk assessment for the change
questions.explanation: Updating the project management plan ensures that all project documents reflect the approved change and guide project execution.

questions.question: Stakeholders request additional features for the project deliverable. How should the project manager handle this request?
options: Approve the additional features without assessment
Assess the impact of the additional features on project scope, schedule, and budget, and then seek approval through the change control process
Reject the request to prevent scope creep
Implement the features and inform stakeholders later
questions.explanation: Assessing the impact and following the change control process ensures that changes are managed systematically.

questions.question: A project manager needs to integrate a new change request. What steps should they take?
options: Approve the change request and implement it
Submit the change request to the change control board (CCB) for evaluation
Document the change and inform stakeholders
questions.explanation: Submitting the change request ensures it is reviewed and approved before implementation.

questions.question: What should a project manager do if a change request is rejected by the change control board (CCB)?
options: Inform stakeholders of the rejection and document the decision
Escalate the rejection to the project sponsor
questions.explanation: Informing stakeholders and documenting the decision ensures transparency and proper record-keeping.

questions.question: During project execution, a major change is requested by a stakeholder. What should the project manager do?
options: Reject the change as it was not in the original plan
Evaluate the impact of the change on the project constraints
Ignore the change, as it came too late
questions.explanation: If a change is requested, regardless of when it arrives, the project manager should evaluate its impact on the project's scope, schedule, cost, and quality before making a decision.

questions.question: Reviewing your project's performance reveals a significant variance. Your project might be canceled if the issue is not fixed before the next customer inspection. However, after a further review conducted by the project team, you are glad to hear that bringing the project back on track requires only a minor correction to a configuration element. What should you do first?
questions.explanation: A change request should be submitted and approved through the project's integrated change control process before implementing any changes. This ensures that all changes are documented, evaluated, and approved before implementation.

questions.question: The project team rigorously defined the project scope during project planning. During project execution, a team member suggests a modification that could improve the project outcome. What should the project manager do next?
options: Ignore the suggestion, as the project scope was rigorously defined
Discuss the change with the project sponsor
Evaluate the impact of the proposed change on the project constraints
Ask that the team member submit a change request
questions.explanation: Any proposed changes to the project, regardless of the source, should be formally documented and evaluated through the change control process. This begins with a change request.

questions.question: If your team has already defined the high-level project schedule constraints, what project management process group are you presently in?
questions.explanation: The team is supposed to define the high-level project restrictions during the initiating process group.

questions.question: Your team has just completed the preliminary project schedule and budget. What should happen next?
questions.explanation: Prior to risks (especially risks connected to quality and communications (Letter A), quality standards and communication criteria must be met. You cannot begin iterations (letter C) until you have completed identifying, qualifying, and quantifying risks, as well as establishing appropriate responses. As a result, you must go over the work breakdown structure (WBS) and other aspects of the project management plan. The Gantt chart (letter A) would have been created as part of the schedule, so this cannot be the next step. Letter B is the correct response from the options provided.

questions.question: During the beginning process group, which of the following is not regarded as an input?
questions.explanation: Take note of the fact that this question asks, which is NOT an input during the initiating process group. Always read the question carefully before responding. Letter a (project scope declaration) is an OUTPUT, not an INPUT, of the planning process group.

questions.question: Typically, successful project integration necessitates a focus on:
options: Effective communication at critical interaction points
questions.explanation: Have you noticed that the most crucial option is required in this question? In this situation, you must analyze what is involved in the establishment of the integration project management plan, integration change control, and project management plan. If one action demands integration with other aspects, effective communication is required before you can integrate the project components into a coherent whole. Other forms of interface should be permitted, and one team member should be integrated with another. Letters a and c are part of the monitoring and controlling phase, whereas letter c demands additional control. The letter d is associated with project management plan implementation.

questions.question: Which of the following is the best use for a work authorization system:
options: Control who performs an activity and when it is completed
Control when each action is finished
Control when and in what order tasks are accomplished
questions.explanation: The schedule and responsibility assignment matrix are used to govern who does which activities (letters a and d). The project schedule (letter b) is used to manage when each activity is done. A work authorization system is primarily used to integrate when and how activities are completed so that activities and staff may efficiently connect with other activities and team members.

questions.question: Which of the following does not constitute an effective change management plan:
questions.explanation: A change management plan includes procedures and processes that enable smooth evaluation and change monitoring. Lessons learned (letter a) are not part of the system, but they can give you with an overview of the procedures and processes that can be improved.

questions.question: Your project has plenty of project charter modifications. Who is in charge of making the necessary changes?
questions.explanation: Keep in mind that the sponsor creates the project charter; thus he or she must assist you in keeping the charter changes under control. In this instance, the charter revisions are mostly the responsibility of the sponsor.

questions.question: What is the main purpose of a project management plan?
options: To communicate project requirements to stakeholders
To provide a guideline for making project decisions
To document project constraints and assumptions
questions.explanation: A project management plan is a formal document that defines how a project is managed, executed, and controlled. It includes various subsidiary plans and can serve all the purposes mentioned in the options.

questions.question: Which document formally authorizes a project's existence and gives the project manager the authority to apply organizational resources to project activities?
questions.explanation: The Project Charter is a document that formally authorizes a project's existence and gives the project manager the authority to apply organizational resources to project activities.

questions.question: What are the five process groups in project management according to the PMBOK Guide?
options: Initiation, Planning, Executing, Monitoring & Controlling, and Closing
Beginning, Planning, Doing, Checking, and Ending
Scoping, Organizing, Implementing, Quality Assurance, and Finalizing
Launch, Development, Execution, Oversight, and Completion
questions.explanation: These are the five project management process groups described in the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK) Guide.

questions.question: A project charter is typically authorized by:
questions.explanation: The project sponsor or initiator usually authorizes the project charter.

questions.question: The project management team is responsible for a multitude of activities. All of the following are part of the project management team's responsibilities, except:
options: Creating a project charter that officially authorizes a project or project phase to proceed and aligns with the project's business objectives and goals
Taking necessary actions to ensure the project is executed in accordance with the project management plan, the planned set of integrated processes, and the planned scope
Assigning multiple team members to tasks to ensure that backup is available in case of illness or other absences
Documenting specific criteria for product requirements, meeting product and project goals as specified in the project charter, and closing the project
questions.explanation: While it's important to have backup resources in case of illness or other absences, this is typically a resource management responsibility, not the project management team. The project management team is responsible for higher-level tasks such as developing the project charter and ensuring the project is performed according to the project management plan.

questions.question: All of the following are efforts included in and conducted to identify, define, combine, unify, and coordinate various processes and project management activities, except:
options: Developing an estimate of the cost of resources
Completing work packages to meet requirements
Releasing team members and updating the skills database
questions.explanation: Releasing team members and updating the skills database is typically part of the project closure process, not the process of identifying, defining, combining, unifying, and coordinating various processes and project management activities.

questions.question: Documenting the business needs, project justification, current understanding of the customer's requirements, new product, service, or result that is intended to satisfy those requirements are all primary concerns of Project Charter, but the main purpose of this document is:
options: To identify and authorize the project manager to conduct project activities by the project sponsor
To identify and document business needs, project justification, and customer requirements and to authorize the project manager
To document which project selection methods have been used to select a project based on the strategic goals of the organization and authorize the project manager
To recognize and accept the existence of the project and authorize to apply organizational resources to project activities
questions.explanation: While the project charter does include information about business needs, project justification, and customer requirements, its main purpose is to authorize the project and the project manager formally. This authorization allows the project manager to use organizational resources for project activities.

questions.question: The project aims to assess the feasibility of constructing a wind farm from a technical, economic, and social perspective. The project charter created by the project manager on behalf of the project sponsor is now approved. Which of the following processes should be performed next?
questions.explanation: After the project charter is approved, the next step is identifying the stakeholders. This process involves identifying all people or organizations impacted by the project and documenting relevant information regarding their interests, involvement, and impact on project success.

questions.question: You are about to start planning for a large and complex project. Due to the size of the project, along with the regulatory and environmental considerations, the development of a detailed project management plan will be critical. As a starting point for initial project planning, what is the first thing you should do?
options: Conduct a project kick-off meeting to inform and engage stakeholders and gain commitment
Review the project charter to understand the high-level information about the project
Begin the process of identifying stakeholders so they can be engaged as necessary for project planning
Share the project scope statement with the project team for a common understanding of project deliverables
questions.explanation: The project charter contains high-level information about the project. Reviewing it will provide a good starting point for the project manager to understand its objectives, key stakeholders, risks, and overall scope.

questions.question: A project is divided into three sequential phases. The project's first phase has just been completed, and the second phase is about to begin. What should the project manager do first?
options: Begin the process of directing and managing the project work
Perform the process of identifying the project stakeholders
Start the process of monitoring and controlling the project work
Begin the process of developing the project management plan

Your project has exceeded its budget
questions.explanation: Keep in mind that SPI stands for Schedule Performance Index. You must figure out the earning value in this question. Letter b is the right answer.

questions.question: Earned Value Management (EVM) provides an integrated view of:
questions.explanation: Earned Value Management (EVM) provides an integrated view of project performance regarding cost, schedule, and scope.

questions.question: The project manager uses ________ to measure and analyze the schedule performance of the project.
questions.explanation: Schedule Variance (SV) is a measure used in project management to indicate how much ahead or behind schedule a project is.

questions.question: If the Cost Performance Index (CPI) is less than 1, this indicates:
options: The project is ahead of schedule
questions.explanation: The Cost Performance Index (CPI) measures a project's financial effectiveness and efficiency. If the CPI is less than 1, the project is over budget because it costs more to perform the project than planned.

questions.question: What is the formula for Schedule Performance Index (SPI)?
options: / Earned Value (EV). c) SPI = Planned Value (PV) / Actual Cost (AC)
questions.explanation: The Schedule Performance Index (SPI) measures schedule efficiency on a project. It is the earned value (EV) ratio to planned value (PV). SPI = EV/PV. An SPI of less than 1.0 indicates less work was completed than planned, meaning the project is behind schedule.

questions.question: Which process involves comparing actual project results against the agreed-upon project management plan?
questions.explanation: The Monitor and Control Project Work process, involves tracking, reviewing, and reporting project progress to meet the performance objectives defined in the project management plan.

questions.question: What does this indicate if the Cost Performance Index (CPI) is less than 100%?
options: The project is right on budget
The project budget cannot be determined
questions.explanation: The Cost Performance Index (CPI) measures a project's financial effectiveness and efficiency. The project is over budget if the CPI is less than 100%.

questions.question: A manager who manages a collection of projects grouped together to facilitate effective management to meet strategic business objectives is called a:
questions.explanation: Portfolio refers to a collection of projects or programs grouped together to facilitate effective management to meet strategic business objectives, and the person managing it is called a Portfolio Manager. Portfolio management describes methods for analyzing and collectively managing a group of current or proposed projects based on numerous key characteristics like business objectives, technical strategy, goals, etc.

questions.question: What is the term for the quantifiable criteria that must be met for the project to be considered successful?
questions.explanation: Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) are the measurable values that demonstrate how effectively a project achieves key objectives.

questions.question: The process of tracking, reviewing, and regulating the progress to meet the performance objectives defined in the project management plan is called:
questions.explanation: Monitor and Control Project Work involves tracking, reviewing, and regulating the progress to meet the performance objectives defined in the project management plan.

questions.question: You are a Project Manager of a highly visible and critical project in your company. This project was initiated with much fanfare, and you have some of the best technical experts as a part of the project team. You are in the process planning and detailing the scope of the project when you hear the project is being terminated. What could be the MOST likely cause?
options: The senior management didn't approve the project charter
The project team didn't have required technical expertise
The project sponsor failed to support the project
The project contract was not signed off by the customer
questions.explanation: The answer to this question can be reached by the process of elimination. Since the project is already initiated and is in the planning stage options A, and D can't be true. There is no evidence to believe option B, and the most probable explanation could be the failure to support the project by the sponsor. The term sponsor, by definition, suggests a financial responsibility. This sponsor is thought to "own" the project and is considered responsible for ensuring its success. The sponsor is also typically the one who proposes the project in the first place, whose business unit reaps its benefits.

questions.question: If it becomes clear that the BAC is no longer viable, the project manager develops a forecasted estimate at completion (EAC). Once approved, the EAC effectively replaces the BAC as the cost performance goal. Whether or not EAC is approved, an excellent way of calculating the to-complete performance index is:
options: Cumulative earned value minus the cumulative actual cost
Work remaining divided by funds remaining
Budget multiplied by estimate at completion
Budget divided by cost performance index
questions.explanation: The To-Complete Performance Index (TCPI) measures the cost performance that must be achieved with the remaining resources to meet a specified management goal, expressed as the ratio of the cost to finish the outstanding work to the remaining budget.

questions.question: You are a Project Manager in the early phase of estimating the cost of the project. You use the analogous method of estimating and have come up with the rough order of magnitude. While presenting it to your sponsor and stakeholders, one of the stakeholders asks if you have also done lifecycle costing for the project. What is your BEST response?
options: Project Cost estimating is primarily concerned with cost of the resources needed to complete the project and needn't consider any other costs
Since it is the initial stage of the project, cost details required for lifecycle costing of the project are not available and hence it is not relevant
Lifecycle costing provides the lowest long-term cost of ownership and should be used as a management decision tool, in case of alternatives
Lifecycle costing should be done by the Project Sponsor as it impacts long-term business decisions
questions.explanation: Lifecycle costing provides the lowest long-term cost of ownership and should be used as a management decision tool. Although project cost management is primarily concerned with the cost of the resources needed to complete the project (Option A, partly true), it should also consider the effect of project decisions on the subsequent recurring cost of using, maintaining, and supporting the project. Hence, lifecycle cost analysis can be used to assist management in the decision-making process. Lifecycle costing looks at the entire cost of the product, not just the cost of project.

questions.question: As a Project Manager, you are working with your team to explore alternatives to decrease project cost without compromising on performance or scope of the project. Which of the following techniques are you most probably using?
questions.explanation: Value analysis is also referred to as value management or value methodology (VM). It requires the systematic approach to identify project functions and assign values to those functions to get the functions at lowest overall cost without loss of performance.

questions.question: As a Project Manager for the project in the planning stage, you have derived the cost estimate by estimating the cost of individual work packages. It is summarized to higher levels for reporting and tracking. What would be the range of estimate from the actual?
questions.explanation: This is the definitive range derived during the latter part of the project when project information is available in sufficient detail. The estimate could become more refined to a range of -5 percent to +10 percent from the actual. This estimate is usually derived using the bottoms up estimation technique.

questions.question: You are a Project Manager planning to launch a new product in the market. For this purpose, you are analyzing the existing products in the market to understand their best practices. You also compare industry standards for performance metrics including cost, cycle time, productivity, and quality to come up with your own product metrics. Which of the following activities are you doing?
questions.explanation: Benchmarking is a management tool through which a plan for evaluation, measurement, and improvement is implemented. It is the process of comparing the business processes and performance metrics including cost, cycle time, productivity, and/or quality to another that is widely considered to be an industry standard benchmark or best practice. The objective of Benchmarking is to determine (1) what and where improvements are called for, (2) how other firms achieve their high performance levels, and (3) how to use this information to improve the firm's performance. Option D process analysis is a tool and technique of the quality assurance process which involves following steps in the quality improvement plan to identify needed improvements. Please refer PMBOK® Guide - Fifth Edition Project Quality Management PN 239 for more details.

questions.question: In order to determine the target fuel efficiency for a hybrid car being designed, a Project Manager is looking at published statistics for similar models in the industry. The technique being used is called:
questions.explanation: What the Project Manager is trying to do is essentially look at the industry benchmark and make sure that the product is in line with it. This is the benchmarking technique.

questions.question: The estimating technique that uses the statistical relationship between the historical data and other variables to calculate an estimate for an activity is called:
questions.explanation: Parametric estimating is an estimation technique which utilizes the statistical relationship between a series of historical data and a particular delineated list of other variables. Some examples of these variables include square footage in a construction project and the number of lines or codes that exist in a software application.
