questions.explanation: Agile project management emphasizes on frequent delivery of products to the customer for feedback. The other options are contrary to Agile principles.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is NOT true about a product lifecycle?
options: It starts with conception of a new product and ends with its withdrawal
A product can spawn a single project in its life
The five stages of each product lifecycle are product development, introduction, growth, maturity, and decline
It focuses on managing the properties of a product from a company's business point of view
questions.explanation: A product can spawn a single project in its life. Product lifecycle management (PLM) is the process of managing the entire lifecycle of a product from its conception, through design and manufacture, to service and disposal. PLM integrates people, data, processes, and business systems to provide a product information backbone for companies. The five stages of each product lifecycle are product development, introduction, growth, maturity, and decline. A product can spawn or require many projects over its life.

questions.question: One phase is planned at any given time, and the planning for the next is carried out as work progresses on the current phase and deliverables. Which of the following correctly defines the above text?
questions.explanation: An iterative relationship is where one phase is planned at any given time and the planning for the next is carried out as work progresses on the current phase or deliverable.

questions.question: You work as a Project Manager at the mobile phone chipset manufacturer. As predicted by Moore's law, each year your company introduces new models of mobile phone chipsets which are faster and more powerful than their predecessors. Mobile phone chipsets that are obsolete or do not sell are quickly retired from production. The chipsets' lifecycle begins in R and D, extends to manufacturing, and finally ends with phase out. This cycle is often referred to as:
questions.explanation: A product lifecycle consists of generally sequential, non-overlapping product phases determined by the manufacturing and control need of the organization. For more details on product lifecycle, refer to PMBOK® Guide - Fifth Edition PN 38.

questions.question: You are managing a project which would provide e-learning solutions to your customer. The requirements of this project are not clearly defined in the beginning, and there would be modifications based on customer feedback as the project evolves. You decide to plan as much as you can and begin to create work while continuing the planning. Which of the following techniques would be the most helpful while defining activities for the project?
questions.explanation: Rolling wave planning is a form of progressive elaboration where work to be accomplished in the near term is planned in detail and future work is planned at a higher level of the Work Breakdown Structure. Therefore, work can exist at various levels of detail depending on where it is in the project lifecycle. As more information is known about upcoming events, the higher-level work packages can be decomposed further. Option B templates, which are usually standardized, would not be a very helpful tool for evolving requirements. Option (c) and (d) are not recognized tools and techniques of project time management.

questions.question: You are facing problems decomposing the testing work package into the final activities required to complete the work package. Detailed testing plans and activities cannot be determined until the system is at least 50% developed and more details become available. The system development work package will take at least three months to complete. What is the best way to resolve this problem?
options: Use product analysis techniques such as product breakdown and systems analysis to decompose the system testing work package
Decompose the system development work package now and decompose the system testing work package later
Break down the project into multiple phases so that the system testing work package goes into the second project phase
Consult the project management plan to determine what to do in this situation
questions.explanation: Delaying the decomposition of the system testing work package until later in the project is an example of rolling wave planning. Rolling wave planning is an iterative planning technique in which the work to be accomplished in the near term is planned in detail, while the work in the future is planned at a higher level. Decomposition may not be possible for a deliverable or subcomponent that will be accomplished far into the future. The project management team usually waits until the deliverable or subcomponent is agreed on, so the details of the work breakdown structure (WBS) can be developed. Therefore, the best approach is to use rolling wave planning and decompose the system development work package now, and then decompose the system testing work package later, when more project information becomes available.

questions.question: A servant leader has just been assigned to an upcoming product development project and believes that the project is well-suited to Kanban. However, the development team is unfamiliar with this approach. What is the servant leader's best course of action?
options: Discuss Kanban during a daily standup meeting
Review Kanban at the iteration retrospective
Let the team members learn Kanban on their own
Have the team attend a workshop on Kanban
questions.explanation: The scenario implies that the servant leader wants to use a project management approach with which the development team is unfamiliar. If the servant leader believes that the Kanban approach is the best methodology for the project, then the servant leader has the responsibility to ensure that the development team has the appropriate training to execute the project. Of the available options, conducting a Kanban workshop would be consistent with agile best practices and provide the development with the necessary tools to execute the project.

questions.question: You are leading a project to develop a new web application. Together with your project team you reprioritize the product backlog, determine velocity for the past iterations, and adapt your work plans accordingly. Additionally, you facilitate retrospectives every two weeks. Which of the following processes describes the work you are performing?
questions.explanation: Adaptive life cycles, such as the agile approach, use short cycles to undertake work, review the results, and adapt as necessary. These cycles provide rapid feedback on the work approaches and suitability of deliverables, and generally involve iterative scheduling. The project described in the scenario is using an agile approach as evidenced by the use of the retrospectives, backlog, and iterations. When an agile approach is used, Control Schedule is concerned with conducting retrospectives to correct and improve processes, reprioritizing the backlog, determining the velocity in each iteration, and adjusting the plans accordingly. Therefore, of the choices provided, the work you are performing is best described by the Control Schedule process.

questions.question: You are part of a cross-functional development team piloting an adaptive approach to project management in an organization that has traditionally used a predictive approach. You realize that you have to tailor the template of the schedule management plan. Which of the following components of the template are you likely to tailor the most?
options: The rules of performance measurement, the summary milestones, and the key deliverables
The organizational procedures links, the units of measure, and the project organization charts
The schedule model development, the release and iteration length, and the reporting formats
The project schedule model maintenance, the level of accuracy, and the level of precision
questions.explanation: The question suggests you are carrying out the Plan Schedule Management process. The schedule management plan is the primary output of this process. The schedule management plan establishes the criteria and the activities for developing, monitoring, and controlling the schedule. Of the choices presented, only the schedule model development, the release and iteration length, and the reporting formats are components of the schedule management plan. All three of these components would merit significant tailoring to reflect an adaptive approach to project management. The project schedule model development specifies the scheduling methodology and the scheduling tool used to develop the schedule model. For an adaptive approach, the schedule model will be a selected series of activities needed to complete a high-priority subset of the project scope that can deliver value quickly. The release and iteration length determine the time-boxed events that must be completed and how long it will take to release the iteration. The reporting formats will be driven by the adaptive schedule model and the iteration length. The other answer choices contain components that are not part of the schedule management plan.

questions.question: You meet with your team to determine the life cycle for your project. After analyzing the best way to define and manage requirements, develop deliverables, handle changes, control risk and cost, and engage key stakeholders, the decision is made to select a hybrid life cycle. With the project life cycle selected, how will the product be delivered?
options: As subsets of the overall product
As a single final product at the end of the project
As work packages of the WBS
As product increments based on customer's value
questions.explanation: Predictive and agile project life cycles differ from one another in several aspects. One of them is the way the project product, service, or result is delivered. Predictive projects develop plans up-front and deliver only a single final product (service or result) at the end of the project. Agile projects, on the other hand, deliver working product increments as frequently as possible based on the highest value to the customer. Everything in between is defined as a hybrid delivery. With hybrid project life cycles, the product can be divided into subsets, which are delivered at either pre-defined intervals or as soon as the subsets are completed. Therefore, of the choices provided, with the hybrid life cycle selected, delivering the result of the project as subsets of the final product constitutes the best answer to the question asked.

questions.question: The scrum master, business analyst, programmers, and testers have been assigned to a product development project. The performing organization is well-versed with the traditional waterfall framework but will incorporate scrum for the software development phase of the project. What is the best strategy to ensure that all of the scrum roles and responsibilities are served in the project?
options: Remove the business analyst from the software development phase since that role is only associated with waterfall project management
Mentor the business analyst to serve in the role of the product owner during the software development phase since those roles are closely aligned
Request that one of the programmers serve as the voice-of-the-customer for the purposes of prioritizing the items in the product backlog
Ask the most experienced tester to approve or reject the deliverables during the sprint review as testers are typically most familiar with the product
questions.explanation: The roles typically associated with scrum include the scrum master, development team, and product owner. In this scenario, the product owner is the role that is vacant. Although the business analyst is a role that is typically associated with waterfall projects, the business analyst can also provide support to the team leader and product owner in an agile environment. The business analyst typically works with the customer to determine and refine project requirements and develop the requirements documentation. When agile methodologies are employed, the business analyst may also assist with the development and refinement of the product backlog. With scrum, the product owner is responsible for managing the product backlog and ensuring that it is prioritized according to business value. In this case, the business analyst will likely have much of the necessary skill set to serve as the product owner but will be lacking in knowledge and experience with agile. Thus, the scrum master should mentor the business analyst to close any agile knowledge gaps and ensure that all of the duties related to a product owner are fulfilled.

questions.question: Collecting requirements for the project and creating the WBS has been a daunting task because stakeholders' needs are vague and are only expressed in the most general terms due to the nature of the project. As a result of this uncertainty, the project manager is concerned about excessive changes, wasted work, and rework anticipated during project execution. What is the project manager's best course of action?
options: Develop a project scope statement and decompose it down to the work package level as part of initial project planning
Request that the project team use an iterative and incremental approach to product development with short feedback loops
Implement a robust change control system to only allow for the most important changes to be incorporated into the product
Generate an activity list from what is currently known and use the Kanban board to break the activities down to their tasks
questions.explanation: The scenario describes a situation where, due to the nature of the project, the requirements are not clearly understood and can only be expressed at a high level. This situation presents an obstacle to collecting project requirements and creating a fully decomposed work breakdown structure (WBS) as part of initial project planning. Projects with a high level of uncertainty in requirements benefit from iterative and incremental approaches that allow the project scope to evolve over the course of the project. Demonstrating smaller increments of the product to the relevant stakeholders allows for short feedback loops to keep the evolving product or result of the project in alignment with stakeholder needs and expectations. For example, the project team might use prototypes to gain early feedback on the requirements. All of the incorrect answer choices represent strategies that would be unrealistic for a project with a high degree of uncertainty in the project requirements. Note that incorporating an agile lifecycle within a project management plan would make this a hybrid project.

questions.question: The organization’s leadership wants projects to include more agile methodologies. Before mandating any agile methods to be used in a project, what should be done first?
options: Pause current projects to align them to the new agile cadence
Ask employees to vote on who wants to take part in agile projects
Assess organizational culture and readiness for the transformation
Provide agile training to those who will be part of the pilot project team
questions.explanation: Organizations seeking to blend a traditional plan-driven project management approach with certain agile methodologies should first assess their organizational culture and readiness to undertake such an initiative. Evolving the organization from carrying out its projects using one project management approach to another takes time and is recommended to undertake gradually and incrementally. In the scenario, senior leadership within the organization is promoting the inclusion of more agile practices into the current project methodologies. Such an organizational change to hybrid modalities may or may not be difficult. To know the extent of the difficulty an organization may endure, assessments of the organization’s readiness for learning, adapting, and applying new methods must be done first.

questions.question: Team members are frequently changing during the long timeline of a multi-phase project. The project manager is questioning whether to include agile practices to accommodate the changes. What should the project manager do prior to moving to a hybrid approach?
options: Ensure project finances are secured for the next project phase
Reduce the team size to nine people, plus or minus two
Target a smaller project as a proof of concept to test the feasibility
Evaluate the benefits of incorporating agile practices
questions.explanation: Shifting the management of a project to a hybrid approach is a decision that identifies and evaluates the potential benefits and value, along with any impediments, detriments, and consequences. Weighing the pros and cons of a hybrid approach enables the project manager to understand and appreciate the reason for the new approach. This evaluation also ensures other stakeholders beyond the project team members are on board with the decision and its rationale.

questions.question: An organization is to undertake a multi-phased project. The sponsor wants to pursue the project objectives as they have been planned but also wants to accommodate and adjust to new information and changes in the environment as the project progresses. Which project management approach should the project manager select for this project?
questions.explanation: Determining the most appropriate methodology to manage a project can be difficult. Fortunately, project managers have plenty of tools in their toolbox. One option available to project managers is the ability to blend or utilize various aspects, approaches, and methods from various project management methodologies. This is referred to as a hybrid approach. In the scenario described, going forward with the upfront-developed plans and be agile to incoming data and changing environmental conditions is ripe for a hybrid approach.

questions.question: Michael is working in an agile environment. Currently, he is working on 2 different projects and is not able to focus properly on both the projects. In terms of Lean, what kind of waste is this?

questions.question: An agile practitioner is explaining his team about the relationships between the development team and customer as well as and responsibilities of the development team and customer in agile project management. Which of the following statements is most appropriate with respect to the given?
options: The customer determines how to perform the work, not the development team
The customer defines value and checks the user experience, not the development team
The development team determines which features should be developed first
The development team sets the priority among the features, not the customer
questions.explanation: In agile project management, role and responsibilities of the customer, product owner, development team or other stakeholders are clearly defined. The initial product scope and the corresponding features are defined by the customer or their proxies like a product owner. Not only this, these features are represented in the form of user stories and these user stories are also prioritized by the customer or the product owner according to their values that indicate which story to be developed first. Now, the actual development work is on the team. It is the development team that defines how the work will be performed or what approaches and the techniques will be followed in the development process. And finally, after the development work is completed and team handovers it to the customer, it is the customer who checks the user experience, not the development team. The customer validates whether the delivered product meets the needs and expectations of the customer and the end users.

questions.question: What would be leadership style during Storming phase of the team development?
questions.explanation: In the storming phase, leadership style is coaching. It should be high directive and high supportive.

questions.question: While managing a software upgrade project for your company you realize that your sponsor has high authority in decisions but low interest. What stakeholder management strategy should you employ to ensure the sponsor's continued support?
Development is a critical aspect in a project with large size and regulatory and environmental considerations. What is the first thing you should do as a starting point for initial project planning?
options: Start identifying stakeholders so that you can engage them as required for project planning
Hold a project kick-off meeting with the aim to inform and engage stakeholders and obtain commitment
Review the project charter to get high-level information about the project
Share project scope with the involved team to establish common understanding about project deliverables

questions.question: You are assigned as the project manager to a project which is executed for a customer under Firm Fixed Price (FFP) contract. Your customer informed you this morning that they insist on certain "refinements" of the project scope. They consider them clearly part of the contractual price and require implementation without extra costs or delays. You agree that the requested actions will be beneficial to the project, but believe that they constitute a major change increasing the project scope. However, the customer insists on their position. What should you do next?
options: Accept the request of the customer. Diligently document the additional costs and working hours spent by yourself and the team on the implementation of the change and invoice these to the customer at appropriate rates

Perform earned value analysis to assess the current status of the project and get all the numbers you need to communicate the case to the change control board which then will have to make the best decision regarding the customer request

Check the contract, the project charter, the scope statement and other documents related to the project and the legal relationship. Implement ADR (alternative dispute resolution) procedures if the conflict cannot be resolved otherwise

Talk to the project sales department and find a joint solution with them how to best reject the request considering the commercial and strategic value of the customer to the organization you are working for

questions.question: During a project using agile methods, the project manager must replace all developers short term with different people of similar qualification. The project manager is afraid that the knowledge transfer from the existing staff to the new developers may be incomplete. Which is a working solution to the issue that the project manager may consider?
options: Stop the development process immediately and direct the developers to document the status and next steps in detail for the new team members
Give the "old" and the new developers time to work together in pairs to communicate the status of the software and the upcoming challenges in face-to-face
Outsource the entire development work and use contractual terms that hold the contractor liable for all troubles that originate from the handover of work

questions.question: The scope baseline is used to identify variance on the scope during the project. It consists of the approved version of ______________?
options: Scope statement, WBS with work packages and planning packages, WBS dictionary
Cost baseline, quality baseline, and schedule baseline
Configuration management plan and configuration identification document
Procurement statement of work and project scope statement

questions.question: Which is normally not regarded as an element of cost of quality?
What does the acronym RACI commonly stand for in project management?
options: Responsible, Accountable, to be Consulted, to be Informed

questions.question: Your Scrum project uses sprints that are timeboxed and end with a Sprint retrospective. What should you do after the retrospective before the project enters the next sprint?
options: Refine objectives and specify in detail what is necessary for successful sprint execution
Define new OKRs (objectives and key results) for the next sprint
Define sprint results that should be ready for formal recognition by the project sponsor
Nothing. A time-boxed sprint starts immediately after the end of the previous one

questions.question: What is the primary focus of project integration management?
options: To unify and coordinate various processes and activities

questions.question: What is the goal of scope management in project management?
options: To define and control project scope

questions.question: What is the purpose of the Direct and Manage Project Work process?
options: To execute project work and manage resources

questions.question: What is the purpose of the Perform Integrated Change Control process?
options: To monitor and control project costs
To review and manage change requests

questions.question: Which communication method is best for ensuring a consistent message to a large audience?
What is the purpose of a lessons learned register?
options: To document insights and improvements for future projects

questions.question: What is the role of the Control Costs process?
options: To monitor the project budget and manage cost variances

questions.question: Which process group is responsible for formally completing the project?
What is the purpose of the Develop Project Management Plan process?
options: To consolidate and integrate subsidiary plans into a comprehensive document
To assign tasks to project team members

questions.question: Which type of project management plan outlines how project quality will be managed and assured?
What is a key characteristic of a matrix organizational structure in project management?
options: Project managers have complete authority over resources
Functional managers have limited control over resources
Resources report to both project managers and functional managers
There is no formal project manager role

questions.question: Which Agile methodology emphasizes the use of sprints and incremental delivery?
What is a product backlog in Agile?
options: A list of tasks assigned to each team member
A prioritized list of work items to be completed
A detailed timeline for the project

questions.question: Which role in Scrum is responsible for maximizing the value of the product and managing the backlog?
In Agile, what is a timebox?
options: A fixed period during which specific work must be completed
The process of estimating project timelines

questions.question: What is the primary role of the Scrum Master?
options: To ensure the team follows Agile practices and removes obstacles
To assign tasks to team members
To review and approve completed work

questions.question: In Agile, what is a 'user story'?
options: A task that needs to be completed within a sprint
A description of a feature from the user's perspective
A test case for verifying a feature

questions.question: What is the purpose of velocity tracking in Agile?
options: To measure team productivity over time

questions.question: What is a key characteristic of a self-organizing team in Agile?
options: The team reports directly to the project manager
The team is responsible for managing their own tasks and responsibilities
The team works without any guidance or supervision
The team follows strict rules for task assignments

questions.question: Which Agile ceremony involves reviewing the completed work at the end of a sprint?
What is the purpose of a backlog refinement meeting in Agile?
options: To review and adjust the sprint plan
To improve and clarify items in the product backlog
To assign tasks to the development team

questions.question: In Agile, what is a 'spike'?
options: A short cycle used for testing a new feature
An activity for exploring uncertainty or gathering information
A method for handling sprint backlog items
A tool for monitoring team progress

questions.question: What is the purpose of a sprint backlog?
options: To outline the project's overall scope and timeline
To provide a detailed list of tasks for the sprint

questions.question: What is pair programming in Agile?
options: A coding technique where two developers work together on the same task
A technique for pairing tasks to increase productivity
A method for testing and reviewing code
A tool for tracking project progress

questions.question: In Kanban, what does WIP stand for?
What is the purpose of a sprint review in Agile?
options: To inspect the sprint outcome and adapt the product backlog if necessary
To assign tasks for the next sprint
To identify areas for team improvement

questions.question: Which Agile practice promotes high transparency in workflow and task status?
What does the term 'iteration' refer to in Agile?
options: A planning phase before development starts
A cycle of development where a portion of the project is completed
The testing phase at the end of a project
The documentation process for user stories

questions.question: What is one of the main benefits of using an Agile methodology?
options: It eliminates the need for planning
It ensures predictable timelines and budgets
It allows for flexibility and adaptation to change
It requires less communication with stakeholders

questions.question: In Scrum, what is the purpose of a sprint goal?
options: To outline all tasks for the sprint
To provide a shared objective for the team to achieve during the sprint
To set a fixed deadline for completing the project

questions.question: Why is Waterfall often considered less flexible than Agile?
options: Because it follows a linear process with limited opportunity for feedback
Because it lacks a project management methodology

questions.question: You are managing a software development project. Your company wants to see frequent deliverables in short periods since the project is large, and it will take a long time to complete the project. There are a few dependencies between the features of the project activities. Which of the following scheduling techniques would you use in this case?

Due to the massive number of project stakeholders and the frequent changes in stakeholders' community, you are facing a complexity issue with stakeholder management. Which of the following techniques can help you to facilitate this situation?

Your company decided to suspend some of the low-priority projects due to the financial crisis. The suspension period will continue for at least six months. Your project is also one of the projects that will be suspended. However, you cannot suspend the project since it will be considered as failed if you cannot complete it on time. You explained the situation to the senior management, and they advised you to terminate the project. What should you do next?
options: Handover the completed and incomplete deliverables

questions.question: Jason is working at Meat King, a fast-food company. After several complaints about the drive-thru process, Meat King initiated a project for process improvement. Jason completed the project and the following are the tracked benefits after project completion. Which of the following is an intangible benefit?
options: Drive-Thru customers increased by 7% after the project completion
Complaints about the Drive-Thru service decreased by 88%
Based on a survey, brand perception of the company increased by 9% related to Drive-Thru
Average service cost per Drive-Thru customer has decreased by 17% after project completion

questions.question: Which of the following techniques could you apply, to any project in any industry, as a way of objectively measuring project progress?
questions.explanation: Of these answers, the only technique that allows you to measure performance is answer B. Answer A is a tool and is not able to be used in every project (it is very difficult to use properly in Agile or Scrum projects). Percent complete is a way of giving actuals, and by themselves do not provide a measure of overall project progress. PMBOK Guide, Sixth Edition, Page 261.

questions.question: Which of the following becomes increasingly important when working with virtual teams?
questions.explanation: Virtual teams are those teams that rarely, if ever, meet face-to-face. In this situation where teams rarely meet face-to-face all facets of communication become increasingly important. Things such as tone, content, clarity, technology, time zones, and team cohesion all will become increasingly important. Answers A, D, and C would be a concern for the project manager on every project. PMBOK Guide, Sixth Edition, Pages 311 and 340.

questions.question: As the project manager you have decided to separate the sources of risk by phase and by the WBS. Using this technique you will find the riskiest areas of the project. Which of the following best describes the technique employed?
questions.explanation: While answer B may be correct, it is too general. Answer C is information about risks that could occur sooner in the project. Answer D is a technique used to ensure the quality of the data used to identify and analyze risk. Risk categorization is a technique used to classify risk and can be done through various methods, such as a sample list of risk categories, or it could be done by phase, by the WBS, or by a formal risk breakdown structure. PMBOK Guide, Sixth Edition, Page 405.

questions.question: Which of the following is a true statement regarding the schedule management plan?
options: It may or may not be written depending on the project management approach of the company executives
It can be formal or informal, highly detailed or broad in nature depending on the project, and it is a key input to the Define Activities process
It must be formal and highly detailed prior to project management plan approval
It requires the input of all stakeholders involved in the project and those that will eventually approve the plan
questions.explanation: In the approach from PMI, a schedule management plan will be included in every project, i.e., it must exist. However, it can be formal or informal, broadly framed or highly detailed in nature, depending on the needs of the project. It does not require the input of ALL stakeholders, just those responsible for schedule planning and execution, or those with a high interest in the project. PMBOK Guide, Sixth Edition, Page 181.

questions.question: You have just completed your Sprint Review meeting and the Product Owner is not satisfied with the results. They state that they will not accept the software and will re-adjust the Product Backlog. The team facilitator suggests that the Product Owner attend a meeting to discuss what could be improved to stop this from occurring in the next sprint. They are most likely inviting the Product Owner to what meeting?
questions.explanation: The Retrospective is a process improvement meeting that is held at the end of every sprint. Since the Product Owner was not satisfied with the recent sprint, it would be most appropriate to have them explain their position and the team could collaboratively improve the process to stop this from occurring in the future.

questions.question: One of your project managers is confused about Agile. They understand Agile is a mindset based on the Agile Manifesto 4 Paired Values and 12 Principles. They are confused because they keep hearing about different agile approaches like Scrum, XP, and Lean. You explain that within this framework, every agile team needs to identify their unique __________.
questions.explanation: Agile is a mindset with an incredible number of options. Each team must identify the agile tools and techniques that best meet their individual needs, and in doing so discover their Way of Working.

questions.question: Based on the continuum of project methodologies, an adaptive approach is both:
questions.explanation: Agile is iterative (multiple sprints until we are done) and incremental (working software delivered at the end of each sprint).

questions.question: A project manager leads a software development project in a hybrid environment. During project planning, the project manager identified a risk where a technical resource for a critical path item may not be available when needed. One week before the resource is needed, the technical engineer had a personal emergency and had to take a leave. What should the project manager do next?
options: Consult the risk register for an appropriate planned risk response and implement
Revise the project management plan and move the task to a time when the technical resource will be available
Review the business requirement with stakeholders and exclude the task assigned to the technical resource
Update the lessons learned report and the risk log to reflect that this risk has materialized

questions.question: A project team member is having difficulty delivering assigned tasks for a project that is at risk of being delayed. The main issue is that the team member does not understand a new system that was recently implemented. What should the project manager do?
options: Ask the team member to learn the new system as on-the-job training
Issue a change request to extend the project schedule
Escalate the team member's performance to the project sponsor
Assign an experienced resource to support the team member

questions.question: What is the primary difference between a predictive and an adaptive life cycle?
options: Predictive life cycles are for large projects and adaptive for small
Predictive life cycles are fixed, adaptive allows changes in scope
Predictive life cycles use only experienced project managers; adaptive does not
Predictive life cycles focus on tasks, adaptive focus on teams
questions.explanation: In a predictive life cycle, the scope, time, and cost are determined early in the life cycle. In contrast, an adaptive life cycle is intended to respond to high change levels and ongoing stakeholder involvement.

questions.question: In which development approach would you expect to find a backlog of work?
questions.explanation: In Agile methodologies, the product backlog is a prioritized list of work for the development team derived from the roadmap and its requirements.

questions.question: In the Agile methodology, which of the following roles is responsible for maximizing the value of the product resulting from the work of the development team?
questions.explanation: In Agile, the Product Owner is responsible for maximizing the product's value, managing the product backlog, and working with the team to achieve the project goals.

questions.question: Which project characteristics suggest a hybrid life cycle approach would be suitable?
options: The project has a well-defined scope, but requirements may evolve.
The project is complex and has interdependent tasks.
The project involves a high-risk opportunity with the potential for high rewards.
The project has a large number of stakeholders with diverse interests
questions.explanation: A hybrid life cycle is a combination of predictive and adaptive life cycles and is most appropriate when some aspects of the project are well understood (well-defined scope) while others are expected to change (evolving requirements).

questions.question: While planning, the project manager realizes the project has many unknowns. What should the project manager plan for?
options: More team meetings to discuss potential risks
questions.explanation: Unknown unknowns are risks that have not been identified or anticipated. The project manager should plan for management reserves to cater to these risks.

questions.question: In Agile project management, a potentially shippable product increment is delivered at the end of each:
questions.explanation: In Agile methodologies like Scrum, a potentially shippable product increment is produced at the end of each sprint, a time-boxed iteration.

questions.question: What is a model in the context of project management?
options: A tangible replica of a structure
A thinking strategy to explain a process, framework, or phenomenon
An exact replica of a past successful project
A detailed step-by-step execution plan for the project
questions.explanation: As per the definitions provided, a model in a project management context is a thinking strategy to explain a process, framework, or phenomenon.

questions.question: What does a method signify in project management?
options: The resources used in a project
The means for achieving an outcome, output, result, or project deliverable
The communication plan for a project
questions.explanation: A method in project management is the way to achieve a particular outcome, output, result, or project deliverable.

questions.question: What does the term 'artifact' refer to in project management?
options: A physical model of the project
A template, document, output, or project deliverable
questions.explanation: In project management, an artifact can be a template, document, output, or project deliverable.

questions.question: Why should project teams consider the implications of using models, methods, and artifacts?
options: To avoid unnecessary effort, redundancy, and misleading information
To ensure uniformity across all projects
To keep the project team busy
questions.explanation: Using models, methods, and artifacts should be thought through to avoid unnecessary effort, redundancy, and incorrect or misleading information.

questions.question: Which one is not an advisable reason for using a particular model, method, or artifact in a project?
options: It caters to individual needs versus those of the project team
It aids in achieving the project deliverable
It is useful to the project team and its stakeholders
It does not produce incorrect or misleading information
questions.explanation: Models, methods, or artifacts should benefit the entire project team and its stakeholders, not individual needs.

questions.question: A model that doesn't cater to the project team's needs should be:
options: Modified according to the project's needs
questions.explanation: A model that doesn't cater to the project team's needs should be avoided as it could lead to inefficiencies and may not contribute to the project's success.

questions.question: Which of the following is a potential cost for using models, methods, and artifacts?
options: Time, level of expertise/proficiency in use, impact on productivity
No cost, as these are part of the project management process
Cost of software tools required for their implementation
questions.explanation: Using models, methods, and artifacts has associated costs such as time, level of expertise/proficiency required, and impact on productivity.

questions.question: The use of a method that produces incorrect or misleading information should be:
questions.explanation: Methods that produce incorrect or misleading information can harm the project's success and should therefore be avoided.

questions.question: When is an artifact considered to be adding unnecessary effort?
options: When it is not required as a project deliverable
When it duplicates work or provides no value to the project team and stakeholders
When it is not directly related to the project's goals
When it needs to be updated regularly
questions.explanation: An artifact should be considered as adding unnecessary effort when it doesn't contribute any value or duplicate already done work.

questions.question: In project management, a model can be best described as:
options: A 3D representation of the project plan
A hypothetical representation used to understand complex systems
A predictive tool used to estimate project success
An organizational chart illustrating team hierarchy
questions.explanation: In project management, a model can be a hypothetical representation that helps to understand, describe, or simulate a process or phenomenon.

questions.question: What is the best reason for using a particular model, method, or artifact in a project?
options: It is the latest trend in project management
The team is familiar with its use
It serves the needs of the project team and stakeholders
It's been successful in other unrelated projects
questions.explanation: A model, method, or artifact should be used because it effectively serves the needs of the project team and stakeholders, not because it's trendy or familiar.

questions.question: What is the risk of using a model, method, or artifact that caters to individual needs over those of the project team?
options: It may alienate other team members
It could result in suboptimal project outcomes
It could lead to project cost overrun
questions.explanation: If a model, method, or artifact is used to cater to individual needs rather than the needs of the project team, it could lead to suboptimal project outcomes.

questions.question: The primary purpose of using methods in project management is to:
options: Achieve specific outcomes, results, or deliverables
questions.explanation: The primary purpose of methods in project management is to achieve specific outcomes, results, or deliverables.

questions.question: When should a project artifact be considered for elimination?
options: When it doesn't serve the needs of the project team or its stakeholders
When it's not part of the original project plan
questions.explanation: An artifact should be eliminated when it does not serve the project team's or its stakeholders' needs.

questions.question: In the context of project management, an artifact refers to:
questions.explanation: In project management, artifacts refer to templates, documents, or project deliverables.

questions.question: How should a project team approach use a model that produces misleading information?
options: The model should be used sparingly
The model should be modified to correct the information
The model should be used as is, to challenge the team
questions.explanation: Models that produce misleading information can harm the project's success and should be avoided.

questions.question: Why should a project team avoid using a useless method for them or their stakeholders?
options: It may lead to inefficient use of time and resources
It may cause disagreements within the team
It could be too complex to understand
It could negatively affect the project's budget
questions.explanation: Using a method that does not serve the project team or stakeholders can lead to inefficient use of time and resources.

questions.question: What could be a potential downside of using a model that requires a high level of expertise?
options: It could lead to misunderstandings among the team
It could impact productivity if not everyone is proficient in its use
It could make the project more expensive
questions.explanation: A model requiring a high level of expertise could impact productivity if not all team members are proficient in its use.

questions.question: The use of a method that duplicates effort should be:
options: Applied to all projects for consistency
questions.explanation: Methods that duplicate effort should be avoided whenever possible, as they do not contribute to efficiency or productivity.

questions.question: What are the potential impacts of not considering the associated costs of using models, methods, and artifacts?
options: Underestimation of time and resources needed
questions.explanation: Not considering the associated costs of using models, methods, and artifacts can lead to underestimation of the time and resources needed and misaligning project deliverables.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a factor a project team should consider when choosing models, methods, or artifacts?
options: The cost associated with time, expertise, and impact on productivity
Whether it caters to the needs of the project team
The popularity of the model, method, or artifact
Whether it produces correct and relevant information
questions.explanation: The popularity of the model, method, or artifact should not be a deciding factor when choosing which to use in project management. Instead, factors such as their cost, usefulness to the project team, and their accuracy should be considered.

questions.question: Which of the following can be considered an artifact in project management?
options: A physical object found on the project site
The leadership style of the project manager
questions.explanation: In project management, an artifact can be a template, document, output, or project deliverable, such as a risk management plan.

questions.question: What should be the primary driving factor in choosing a method for project management?
options: It should have a proven track record of success
It should be the easiest method available
It should be capable of achieving the desired outcome, result, or deliverable
It should be the most recent method developed
questions.explanation: The primary driving factor in choosing a method for project management should be its capability to achieve the desired outcome, result, or deliverable.

questions.question: What kind of model is undesirable in a project setting?
options: A model that is based on scientific principles
A model that requires too much time to implement
A model that is too simple to cover all aspects of the project
A model that caters to the needs of the stakeholders
questions.explanation: An undesirable model in a project setting would require too much time to implement, as this can slow down project progress and lead to inefficiencies.

questions.question: In project management, a method should ideally:
options: Be capable of producing the desired outcome, result, or deliverable
Be universally applicable across all projects
questions.explanation: Ideally, a method in project management should be capable of producing the desired outcome, result, or deliverable. While cost-effectiveness and ease of learning are important, they should not be the primary considerations.

questions.question: Why is it important to avoid models that are not useful to the project team?
options: It makes the project manager's job easier
It ensures the project is completed on time
questions.explanation: Avoiding models that are not useful to the project team conserves resources and time, which can be better spent on activities that contribute to the project's success.

questions.question: What is the main purpose of an artifact in project management?
options: To add aesthetic value to the project
To serve as a tangible product, document, or output
To create extra work for the team
questions.explanation: The main purpose of an artifact in project management is to serve as a tangible product, document, or output that contributes to the project's objectives.

questions.question: When should a model that requires a high level of proficiency be used in a project?
options: When it is the only model available
When the team members are experts in its application
When the project manager insists on its use
When the project timeline allows for learning and implementation
questions.explanation: A model that requires a high level of proficiency should be used when the team members are experts in its application. This ensures the model can be effectively and efficiently implemented.

questions.question: What is the potential risk of using a method that duplicates effort in a project?
options: It could lead to an increase in project costs
It could lead to lower morale in the project team
It could lead to confusion and misunderstandings
questions.explanation: Using a method that duplicates effort in a project could lead to increased project costs, lower morale in the project team, and confusion and misunderstandings.

questions.question: What characteristic makes a model valuable to a project?
options: It helps explain a process, framework, or phenomenon
It has been used successfully in past projects
questions.explanation: A valuable model in a project setting helps explain a process, framework, or phenomenon, thus facilitating better understanding and decision-making.

questions.question: Which of the following project artifacts is typically updated regularly throughout the project?
questions.explanation: The project schedule is an artifact typically updated regularly throughout the project to reflect progress and timeline changes.

questions.question: Which of the following methods would be least effective in a project?
options: A method that requires expertise not available in the team
A method that simplifies complex processes
A method that is well-documented and easy to follow
A method that has been effective in similar projects
questions.explanation: A method that requires expertise unavailable in the team would be least effective in a project because it may not be properly or efficiently implemented.

questions.question: In the context of project management, why are models important?
options: They provide a visual representation of the project
They help in understanding complex systems or processes
They serve as a historical record of past projects
They define the roles and responsibilities of the team members
questions.explanation: Models in project management are important because they help understand complex systems or processes, making them easier to manage and control.

questions.question: What could be a potential outcome of using an artifact that is not useful to the project team and its stakeholders?
options: It could slow down project progress
It could make the project more interesting
It could help in future projects
questions.explanation: Using an artifact useless to the project team and its stakeholders could slow progress as it consumes time and resources without adding value.

questions.question: What should be the main criterion for choosing an artifact in project management?
options: It should be easy to create or obtain
It should serve a useful purpose in the project
It should be impressive to stakeholders
It should have been used in previous projects
questions.explanation: The main criterion for choosing an artifact in project management should be its usefulness.

questions.question: What would be a likely consequence of using a model that produces incorrect or misleading information?
options: It might delay the project timeline
It could result in flawed decision-making
questions.explanation: If a model produces incorrect or misleading information, it could lead to flawed decision-making, negatively impacting the project's success.

questions.question: When would a project team choose not to use a particular artifact?
options: When it requires a high level of expertise to create or use
When it is expensive to produce
When it duplicates or adds unnecessary effort
When it is not in line with the latest project management trends
questions.explanation: A project team might choose not to use a particular artifact when it duplicates or adds unnecessary effort, which could lead to inefficiency and waste of resources.

questions.question: What is the key purpose of using methods in project management?
options: To ensure that the project is done in the fastest possible time
To show stakeholders that the project is being managed professionally
To provide a structured way to achieve desired outcomes, results, or deliverables
To make sure that every team member is kept busy
questions.explanation: The key purpose of using methods in project management is to provide a structured way to achieve desired outcomes, results, or deliverables.

questions.question: When selecting models, methods, and artifacts for a project, which of the following should NOT be a consideration?
options: The personal preferences of the project manager
The cost in terms of time, expertise, and productivity
The usefulness to the project team and stakeholders
The accuracy and relevance of the information they provide
questions.explanation: The personal preferences of the project manager should not be a deciding factor when selecting models, methods, and artifacts for a project. Decisions should be based on cost, usefulness, and accuracy, among other factors.

questions.question: Which of the following could be a potential negative impact of using a method that caters to individual needs versus those of the project team?
options: It could create a sense of favoritism within the team
It could limit the project's success
questions.explanation: Using a method that caters to individual needs versus those of the project team could limit the project's success, as it may not fully address the project's requirements or the needs of all team members.

questions.question: Which of the following scheduling techniques considers both resource optimization and uncertainty in estimating activity durations?
questions.explanation: The Critical Chain Method accounts for resource constraints and includes buffers to protect the project schedule from slippage, considering uncertainty in activity duration.

questions.question: Your development team is waiting for the design team to finish its work. As a Project Manager, you have decided to use this approach to reduce uncertainty in the project. Which of the following relationship does this describe?
questions.explanation: A sequential relationship is the stage where a phase can only start once the previous phase is complete. The step-by-step nature of the approach reduces uncertainty but may eliminate options for reducing the schedule.

questions.question: A key stakeholder from the quality department wants to know more on how the process tailoring was done by the project team. Additionally, the stakeholder would like to know the rationale for selecting processes, their implementation level details, and how they will be used to manage the interdependencies. Which document should the Project Manager refer the stakeholder to?
questions.explanation: The results of the process tailoring by the project team are captured in the project management plan, along with all the other information required by the stakeholder.

questions.question: You are a Project Manager working on a critical project. You track the project schedule closely. While going through the critical path, you realize that the project is showing negative float. What is your BEST response to the situation?
options: Reduce the number of resources from the project
Reduce the number of noncritical activities in the project
Revisit the risks and do a risk analysis of the project
questions.explanation: The best option is to compress the project schedule because the critical path activities can be delayed thus resulting in a negative float. In this case, the Project Manager should use a schedule compression technique such as fast tracking or crashing.

questions.question: An activity cannot be started until the predecessor also starts. This is an example of:
questions.explanation: This is an example of a start-to-start dependency. It means that B can't start before A starts, or in other words Activity B can start after Activity A has started.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about critical path is TRUE?
options: It is the shortest path from start to finish
All the activities on the critical path do not have any float
A project will have only one critical path
A critical path takes into consideration logical as well as resource dependencies
questions.explanation: Critical path activities do not have any float. If any activity on the critical path is delayed, the completion of the project will be delayed by an equal amount. To determine the critical path, you have to add the amount of time estimated for the duration of each activity to the previous activity.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of Lead?
options: Pillars for a structure can be started 7 days after the foundation to allow for curing
Test lab preparation can start 5 days before a product is made available for test
Both test planning and product development can start simultaneously after the design is finalized
Crash tests cannot be carried out until a working final model is made available
questions.explanation: Lead means that the successor activity can start in advance of the predecessor activity.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a likely outcome of trying to fast track a project?
questions.explanation: Fast tracking (getting more tasks to go on in parallel) may reduce the time taken but will likely increase risk and rework.

questions.question: Procurement management plan is developed based on:
questions.explanation: According to the new examination content outline, budget is also included. Earlier it was based on scope and schedule.

questions.question: Baselines are an important input to a number of project processes. Outputs of many processes raise change requests to these baselines. Which of the following is not a valid project baseline?
questions.explanation: Risk baseline is not a valid project baseline. It is an accepted and approved project plan.

questions.question: You are about to start planning for a large and complex project. Due to the size of the project along with the regulatory and environmental considerations, the development of a detailed project management plan will be critical. As a starting point for initial project planning, what is the first thing you should do?
options: Conduct a project kick-off meeting to inform and engage stakeholders and gain commitment
Review the project charter to understand the high-level information about the project
Begin the process of identifying stakeholders so they can be engaged as necessary for project planning
Share the project scope statement with the project team for a common understanding of project deliverables
questions.explanation: The question states that project planning is about to begin which suggests that project initiation has been completed. The project charter is created during the Develop Project Charter process as part of project initiation. The project team uses the project charter as a starting point for initial project planning. The type and amount of information in the project charter varies depending on the complexity of the project and the information known at the time of its creation. At a minimum, the project charter should define the high-level information about the project that will be elaborated in the various components of the project management plan.

questions.question: The project is in execution, but your project team is unable to stop arguing about the project milestones and the specific risks associated with them. This on-going conflict puts the project at risk of running behind schedule. What would likely have helped avoid this conflict had it been properly created first?
questions.explanation: The WBS is considered by many project managers to be the heart of the projects lead by a predictive project management approach since a WBS lists the total scope of work to be carried out by the project team to accomplish the project objectives and create required deliverables. The milestone list is an output from the Define Activities process to which the WBS serves as an input (as part of the scope baseline). The risk register is an output from the Identify Risks process to which the WBS serves as an input (as part of the scope baseline) used as a framework to structure risk identification techniques. Had the project manager and the team taken the time to create a proper WBS, it is likely the team would have had a more accurate milestone list and risk register with which to finish their project management plan on time and avoid the conflict described in the scenario.

questions.question: A project manager meets with a customer for initial discussions about an upcoming project. At the end of the meeting, the customer asks the project manager for a rough estimate of the project duration. Based on her experience with three similar projects, the project manager provides an estimate of 8-10 months. What estimation technique does the project manager use?
questions.explanation: The project manager is using historical duration information from comparable projects to estimate the duration of a future project. This gross value estimating approach is called analogous estimating and is frequently used to provide a ballpark figure when there is a limited amount of detailed information available about the project.

questions.question: A project is underway to construct a wind farm in an area with no communication infrastructure. The plan is to monitor progress and coordinate the scheduling of the project activities using project management software and provide daily status updates to the project sponsor at the home office. Two project teams will work and reside onsite in rotating seven-day tours. Which of the following is the most likely challenge the teams will face while controlling the schedule?
questions.explanation: Each project is unique. Therefore, the project manager may need to tailor the way Project Schedule Management processes are applied. Technology support is among the considerations for tailoring that should be kept in mind while planning the project under the circumstances described in the scenario. The question presents a situation where a project is being conducted in a desolate area without any existing infrastructure for technology support. This circumstance means that there are no cellular towers or Wi-Fi and no readily available means of communication. Concerning controlling the schedule, the project manager must consider how the project management software, including the project schedule, will be updated and submitted daily to the home office. The project manager may need to acquire the necessary equipment to use satellite technology and reconsider the content and frequency of the project status updates. Therefore, of the available choices, technology support is the best answer to the question asked.

questions.question: As a project manager, you are in the process of estimating the team resources that will be required for your project. The challenge you are having is that, due to the nature of the project and the selected development approach, only a few of the top levels of the WBS have been identified with the remainder to be progressively elaborated throughout the project. What is the best approach to determine the team resource requirements for the project?
options: Check the organizational process assets for similar projects and use analogous estimating
Apply bottom-up estimating using the work breakdown structure (WBS) as a guide
Utilize parametric estimating for the individual work packages within the existing WBS
Decompose the WBS down to the work package level during initial project planning
questions.explanation: The question suggests that you, as the project manager, are performing the Estimate Activity Resources process and that a hybrid development approach is being utilized. When incorporating agile practices within an overarching traditional waterfall approach, the project scope may be progressively elaborated throughout the project, and the work breakdown structure (WBS) may not be fully decomposed during initial project planning. Under such circumstances, one viable approach to estimating team resource requirements would be to utilize the analogous estimating technique. If there are past similar projects, the organizational process assets (OPAs) should contain detailed information that could be used for analogous estimating.

questions.question: One of the project activities requires that a search of a large area is conducted to find debris from an explosion of a failed prototype. The project is now in planning, and there is a debate among the team members on the type and quantity of resources needed to complete this activity. What should the project manager do first?
options: Select any resource and quantity to complete the task by the due date
Request the team to vote and make a decision based on majority
Research various levels of resource capability and skills, types, and sizes
Utilize a PMIS to manage resource pools and allocate resources
questions.explanation: The question implies the team is carrying out the Estimate Activity Resources process. This process uses many tools and techniques. One technique to understand the resource needs and the best potential solutions for the activity resources is data analysis. Data analysis can be conducted in many forms and formats. The objective is to evaluate possible options or approaches or values to determine the best activity resource estimates. Once a value or a range of values has been determined as reasonable, estimates can be set or decisions that are most suitable for the participants made. Therefore, of the choices provided, before making any decision, researching various resources levels, types, and methods is what the project manager should do first.

questions.question: You are in the process of developing an approximation of the monetary resources needed to complete project work for a large-scale multinational project which will take at least seven years to complete. Your previous projects have all been domestic with short timeframes. As part of the process you are currently performing, what might you need to do differently compared with your past projects?
options: Create a stakeholder engagement assessment matrix
Develop a more robust risk management plan
questions.explanation: Developing an approximation of the monetary resources needed to complete project work is the main objective of the Estimate Costs process. Therefore, the question implies that you are conducting the Estimate Costs process and asks how this process will be affected by a large long-term multinational project. Thus, the answer choices that relate to other project management processes can be eliminated as correct responses. With the project lasting at least seven years, the impact of inflation over the course of the project must be considered. Additionally, since the project is international in scope, the project will likely be working with various currencies that will be subject to fluctuations in relative values. For large-scale projects that extend multiple years with multiple currencies, the fluctuations of currencies and inflation need to be understood and built into the Estimate Costs process. Exchange rates and inflation are considered enterprise environmental factors. Therefore, of the available choices, considering additional enterprise environmental factors is the best response.

questions.question: Progressive Elaboration Means:-
options: Distinct processes are developed for each project
Implementation of the project must follow strictly according to the initial project management plan
Project Management Plans must be elaborate in order to be effective
Project processes are iterated as more information is uncovered throughout the project life cycle

questions.question: One member of the agile team, Vicky was not able to concentrate on his work in the team area. He approached scrum master and requested separate area where he can concentrate and work. Rosy (Scrum master) said since whole agile team sits at the same location so Vicky has to work there itself. Being an Agile Coach, what would you do in such a situation?
options: Agree with Rosy and ask Vicky to work at the same location
Ask Rosy to give separate cubicle to Vicky
Ask whole team not to make noise as it is disturbing others
Coach Rosy that Agile supports Caves and Common and ask her to allow Vicky to work in cave for brief period of time
questions.explanation: In Caves and Common, agile team members are allowed to work in quiet area for a while, if they are not able to concentrate in the team area. Once done, team member should return to the common area.

questions.question: In which of the following technique, development team integrates new work into the already existing product and then ensures it works as per the desired plan.
questions.explanation: Continuous integration involves frequent integration of new piece of work into existing product and ensuring nothing breaks down during integration.

questions.question: The development team gathered to break user stories into tasks. The team is involved in which ceremony?
questions.explanation: In the iteration planning, team discuss user stories and breaks them into tasks at the last responsible moment. Tasks are the smallest chunks of work required to build the story.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true?
options: In Agile, Risk is high at the beginning and then decreases rapidly
In Agile, Risk is high at the beginning and then decreases and after sometimes it increases
In Agile, Risk is low at the beginning and then increases and after sometimes it decreases
In Agile, Risk remains low throughout the project
questions.explanation: In Agile, high risk items are placed at the top of the product backlog which ensures they are developed at the earlier stage. This helps in decreasing risk rapidly as the project progresses.

questions.question: You have just completed your Agile training and are confident you know all there is to know about the topic. You are discussing it with a senior Scrum Master and mention that all Agile approaches are based on Scrum and use a backlog. He explains that there is another approach that does not use a backlog, but it does normally use a tool that is common to backlog based Agile. He is most likely describing what?
questions.explanation: Kanban, or flow based agile, is used when there is little need for coordination and the work is roughly the same size. There is no sprint, rather work is pulled into process based on priority and availability of resources.

The project manager is confused since the entire team is located in the same time zone and believes there are other factors at play. What should the project manager do next?
